description: From Middle French philtre, from Ancient Greek φίλτρον (phíltron), from φιλέω (philéō, “I love”).

entries.meaning: A kind of potion, charm, or drug; especially a love potion intended to make the drinker fall in love with the giver. [from the 16th c.]

verbs.description: philter (third-person singular simple present philters, present participle philtering, simple past and past participle philtered)

entries.meaning: To impregnate or mix with a love potion.
To charm to love; to excite to love or sexual desire by a potion.
examples: Let not those that have repudiated the more inviting sins, shew themselves philtred and bewitched.
